noun.description: A person or thing that gives rise to an action, phenomenon, or condition.
examples: the cause of the accident is not clear

noun.description: A principle, aim, or movement that, because of a deep commitment, one is prepared to defend or advocate.
examples: she devoted her life to the cause of deaf people
I'm raising money for a good cause

noun.description: A matter to be resolved in a court of law.

examples: we have no idea what has happened to cause people to stay away

phrases: Even at that stage in his life he had discovered the principle of cause and effect.
Hume suggested that we cannot apply to law of cause and effect to our world - we cannot say for sure that one thing causes another.
The concept of cause and effect is the basis of karma, the Threefold Law, and even physics.
Do the planners and politicians understand the law of cause and effect?
But, according to Hume, the principle of cause and effect cannot be derived from experience.
origin: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin causa (noun), causare (verb).
